objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to establish a workflow using Large Language Models (LLMs) like OpenAI ChatGPT and Google Gemini Pro to create knowledge maps that identify important process steps for materials, valuable relationships, important property data, and list salient outcomes of research articles. This approach aims to develop a high-throughput, strong context-based material database extracted from available open literature.
objective.evidence: Our primary objective is to establish a work flow using LLMs models like OpenAI ChatGPT (GPT-3.5-turbo-1106) and Google Gemini Pro for creating knowledge maps (graphs) that identifies important process steps for materials, valuable relationships, important property data and lists salient outcomes of research articles.

knowledge_gap.answer: The paper addresses the gap in efficiently analyzing research papers for high-throughput data collection, particularly the lack of structured outputs when dealing with individual paragraphs in materials science literature.
knowledge_gap.evidence: Efficiently analyzing research papers has been a long-standing challenge within the academic community. Traditional methods often require researchers to invest substantial time in reading and deciphering complex papers. Although being robust, this method may not be the most suited for high–throughput data collection.

answer: The paper introduces a novel workflow using LLMs to create knowledge maps from research articles.
It presents a new method for extracting structured information from text and images in research papers.
The study demonstrates the integration of textual and visual components to enhance comprehension.
The work proposes a specific prompt engineering approach to improve the extraction of material science data.
evidence: Our primary objective is to establish a work flow using LLMs models like OpenAI ChatGPT (GPT-3.5-turbo-1106) and Google Gemini Pro for creating knowledge maps (graphs).
A novel text and image extraction approach allows to systematically capture section–specific text and images from the portable document format (pdf) files of journal articles.
The structured responses generated by the zero-shot LLMs models are seamlessly merged with the associated images that are referenced within the employed structured format.
The novelty of our work lies in devising a specific prompt to identify the desired linkages using LLMs.

inspirational_papers.answer:
- Kim et al. (2017) Materials synthesis insights from scientific literature via text extraction and machine learning. (Methodological precursors)
- Jensen et al. (2019) A machine learning approach to zeolite synthesis enabled by automatic literature data extraction. (Methodological precursors)
- Shetty and Ramprasad (2021) Automated knowledge extraction from polymer literature using natural language processing. (Methodological precursors)
inspirational_papers.evidence: Some of the earliest applications of NLP in materials science are seen in the work of Kim et al [8], Jensen et al [9] who used NLP for automated data extraction for accelerated synthesis of metal oxide and zeolites respectively. Shetty and Ramprasad [10] applied NLP for automated extraction of knowledge on a corpus of 0.5 M journal articles.

steps.step: Data collection and extraction of knowledge graphs and data tables from journal articles.
steps.evidence: In this work, the collected text from the journal articles has been used to extract knowledge graphs, construct data tables.

steps.step: Tokenization and stemming to extract textual insights.
steps.output: Tokens and root forms of words.
steps.evidence: In the initial phase of our data collection approach, advanced techniques are employed such as tokenization and stemming to extract significant textual insights from research papers.

steps.step: Extraction of structured information using specialized prompts.
steps.evidence: To extract structural data and numerical values from material science research papers, specialized prompts are utilized that are designed to guide prompt-based LLMs models utilizing ChatGPT and Gemini models.

steps.step: Generation of knowledge graphs from extracted data.
steps.input: Extracted essential information and significant data.
steps.evidence: The process involves extracting essential information and significant data from text using these models. It is then converted into JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) format.

tools.name: OpenAI ChatGPT (GPT-3.5-turbo-1106)
tools.description: Used for creating knowledge maps and extracting structured information from text.
tools.evidence: Our primary objective is to establish a work flow using LLMs models like OpenAI ChatGPT (GPT-3.5-turbo-1106) and Google Gemini Pro for creating knowledge maps (graphs).

tools.name: Google Gemini Pro
tools.description: Used for creating knowledge maps and extracting structured information from text.
tools.evidence: Our primary objective is to establish a work flow using LLMs models like OpenAI ChatGPT (GPT-3.5-turbo-1106) and Google Gemini Pro for creating knowledge maps (graphs).

evaluation_metrics.name: ROUGE
evaluation_metrics.purpose: Measures similarity through precision, recall, and F1 score between generated text and reference texts.
evaluation_metrics.application: Used to assess the structured text generated by LLM models.
evaluation_metrics.evidence: To assess the structured text within the engineering domain generated by LLM models OpenAI ChatGPT (GPT-3.5-turbo-1106) and Google Gemini Pro, we adopt the Recall-Oriented Understudy for Gisting Evaluation (ROUGE) metric.

methods.name: Transformation/structurization of user input
methods.description: The approach involves transforming unstructured text into structured formats like knowledge graphs.
methods.evidence: The process involves extracting essential information and significant data from text using these models. It is then converted into JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) format.

methods.name: Knowledge Extraction and Structurization
methods.description: The method extracts structured information from unstructured data using LLMs.
methods.evidence: To extract structural data and numerical values from material science research papers, specialized prompts are utilized that are designed to guide prompt-based LLMs models utilizing ChatGPT and Gemini models.

areas.name: Applied Sciences & Engineering
areas.description: The paper focuses on creating knowledge maps for materials engineering using LLMs.
areas.evidence: This work contributes to accelerated material design by smart literature review.

performance_summary.summary: The Google Gemini Pro outperforms ChatGPT with an F1 score of 0.50 for an exact match and 0.63 for a relaxed match.
performance_summary.evidence: The Google Gemini Pro outperforms ChatGPT with an F1 score of 0.50 for an exact match and 0.63 for a relaxed match.

evaluation_metrics.name: ROUGE
evaluation_metrics.purpose: Measures similarity through precision, recall, and F1 score between generated text and reference texts.
evaluation_metrics.application: Used to assess the structured text generated by LLM models.
evaluation_metrics.evidence: To assess the structured text within the engineering domain generated by LLM models OpenAI ChatGPT (GPT-3.5-turbo-1106) and Google Gemini Pro, we adopt the Recall-Oriented Understudy for Gisting Evaluation (ROUGE) metric.

limitations.name: Limited Comprehension of Complex Processes
limitations.description: LLMs face challenges in comprehending intricate fabrication methodologies crucial for attaining specified material properties.
limitations.evidence: Despite LLMs capability to identify items and establish linkages, it encounters difficulty in comprehending the primary materials related processes and significant scientific details from the provided text.

future_directions.name: Establish a Structured Evaluation Method
future_directions.description: Develop a method for evaluating the quality of generated knowledge graphs from unstructured text.
future_directions.evidence: Looking ahead, the future research has a few directions. Initially, the aim is to establish a structured method for evaluating the quality of the generated knowledge graphs from unstructured text.

future_directions.name: Extend Approach to Different Domains
future_directions.description: Expand the methodology to other scientific domains and develop a generalized model.
future_directions.evidence: Additionally, the vision is to extend this approach to different domains and a generalized model to do it.

resource_link.evidence: The tool can be tested at padarthproject.org.
